edu.rit.pj2

Class WorkerParallelForLoop

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.rit.pj2.ParallelStatement
      • edu.rit.pj2.ParallelForLoop
        • edu.rit.pj2.WorkerParallelForLoop

  • public class WorkerParallelForLoop
extends ParallelForLoop
    Class WorkerParallelForLoop provides the worker portion of a master-worker cluster parallel for loop.

    Programming. To program a master-worker cluster parallel for loop, you must program the master portion in the Job, and you must program the worker portion in a worker Task. To program the master portion, in the Job subclass's main() method:

    • Optionally, define the job's workers, masterSchedule, and masterChunk properties by calling the workers(), masterSchedule(), or masterChunk() methods. These properties can also be specified on the pj2 command line. If any property is not specified, a default value is used.

    • If the loop index is type int, call the masterFor(int,int,Class) method, specifying the loop index inclusive lower and upper bounds along with the worker task class.

    • If the loop index is type long, call the masterFor(long,long,Class) method, specifying the loop index inclusive lower and upper bounds along with the worker task class.

    • The masterFor() method returns a TaskSpec object. Optionally, call methods on the task specification object to configure the worker tasks.

    To program the worker portion, in the worker Task subclass's main() method:

    • Call the workerFor() method, which returns a WorkerParallelForLoop object.

    • Optionally, define the worker parallel for loop's threads, schedule, and chunk properties by calling the threads(), schedule(), or chunk() methods on the WorkerParallelForLoop object. These properties can also be specified on the pj2 command line. If any property is not specified, the enclosing task's property is used.

    • If the loop index is type int, call the exec(Loop) method, specifying the parallel for loop body, which is an instance of class Loop. See class Loop for further information.

    • If the loop index is type long, call the exec(LongLoop) method, specifying the parallel for loop body, which is an instance of class LongLoop. See class LongLoop for further information.

    Operation. Under the hood, the master-worker cluster parallel for loop operates as follows. There is one master and there are K worker tasks, where K is given by the job's workers property. (The default is one worker task.) In the job, the master partitions the loop index range into a series of Chunk tuples (for an int loop index) or LongChunk tuples (for a long loop index), and puts these tuples into tuple space. The partitioning is specified by the job's masterSchedule and masterChunk properties. (The default is a fixed schedule. See enum Schedule for further information about the possible schedules.) The master also adds a rule to the job with a task group of K worker tasks. The worker tasks start executing when the job starts.

    In each worker task, when the exec() method is called, the worker sets up a team of T threads, where T is given by the worker parallel for loop's threads property. (The default is one thread for each core of the machine where the worker task is running.) Each team thread operates on its own copy of the Loop object. Each team thread calls its loop object's start() method. The worker repeatedly takes a Chunk or LongChunk tuple from tuple space and performs the loop iterations specified by that chunk. The chunk's iterations are partitioned among the team threads as specified by the worker parallel for loop's schedule and chunk properties. (The default is a fixed schedule. See enum Schedule for further information about the possible schedules.) Each team thread performs a series of iterations by calling its loop object's run() method repeatedly. When all the team threads have finished all the iterations for all the chunks, each team thread calls its loop object's finish() method.

    Thus, a master-worker cluster parallel for loop has two levels of loop iteration partitioning: the job level specified by the masterSchedule and masterChunk properties, and the worker task level specified by the schedule and chunk properties. These properties can be used to achieve load balancing in a cluster parallel program. Generally, coarse-grained (large) chunks are used at the job level and fine-grained (small) chunks are used at the task level.

    Early loop exit. To terminate a master-worker cluster parallel for loop before all the loop iterations have been executed:

    • Tell all the worker tasks to terminate execution. This is typically done by putting a special "stop tuple" into tuple space, and having each worker task take that tuple in a separate thread.

    • Tell the worker parallel for loop in each task to terminate execution. This is done by calling the stop() method inside the loop's run() method once the stop tuple appears.

    Warning. There can be only one master-worker cluster parallel for loop in a job.

    See Also:
    Loop, LongLoop

    • Method Detail

      • threads

        public WorkerParallelForLoop threads(int threads)
        Set this parallel for loop's threads property. The threads property specifies the number of threads that will execute this parallel for loop. The default is the threads property of the enclosing task. For further information, see the threads() method of class Task.
        Parameters:
        threads - Number of threads (≥ 1), or Task.DEFAULT_THREADS.
        Returns:
        This parallel for loop object.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if threads is illegal.

      • schedule

        public WorkerParallelForLoop schedule(Schedule schedule)
        Set this parallel for loop's schedule property. The schedule property, along with the chunk property, specifies how the iterations of this parallel for loop are partitioned among the threads executing this parallel for loop. Refer to enum Schedule for descriptions of the possible schedules. The default is the schedule property of the enclosing task. For further information, see the schedule() method of class Task.
        Parameters:
        schedule - Parallel for loop schedule.
        Returns:
        This parallel for loop object.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if schedule is null.
        See Also:
        chunk(int)

      • chunk

        public WorkerParallelForLoop chunk(int chunk)
        Set this parallel for loop's chunk property. The chunk property, along with the schedule property, specifies how the iterations of this parallel for loop are partitioned among the threads executing this parallel for loop. Refer to enum Schedule for descriptions of the possible schedules. The default is the chunk property of the enclosing task. For further information, see the chunk() method of class Task.
        Parameters:
        chunk - Chunk size (≥ 1), or Task.DEFAULT_CHUNK.
        Returns:
        This parallel for loop object.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - (unchecked exception) Thrown if chunk is illegal.
        See Also:
        schedule(Schedule)
